facts.text: The appellants Company registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913 was assessed in the assessment years 1948-49 to 1953-54 in respect of the profits earned in its business, and was allowed rebate under the appropriate provisions contained in the Schedules to the relevant Finance Acts on the undistributed profits of the previous years.
On December 31, 1956 at an annual general meeting of the shareholders the Company declared an aggregate sum of Rs. 2,15,232/- as dividend for the year ending December 31, 1956.
Thereafter a special resolution was passed for voluntary winding up of the Company with effect from October 1, 1957, and for appointing a liquidator to wind up the affairs of the Company.
On October 20-21, 1957 the liquidator distributed to the shareholders.
Thereafter on February 21-22, 1958 the liquidator distributed to the shareholders.
July 27, 1959 the liquidator distributed to the shareholders.
In respect of each liquidator issued an income-tax refund that the amount was distributed out of accumulated profits of earlier years.

The Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle-B, Ahmedabad in exercise of the power under s. 35(10) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, passed an order withdrawing the rebate, granted in respect of each of the six assessment years 1948-49 to 1953-54 and demanded payment of tax on the amount of the rebate.

The appellant then applied to the High Court of Bombay for writs quashing the orders of the Income-tax Officer and the notice of demand and directing the Income-tax Officer to withdraw and cancel the order and notice of demand.
The petition was dismissed by the High Court.
Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 16, 17, 1961 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 233 of 1960.
With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

legal_issues.text: Whether S. 35(10) authorises the Income-tax Officer to bring to tax rebate granted in assessment years commencing prior to April 1, 1956

Whether distribution by the liquidator of accumulated profits in the previous years could be regarded as declaration of dividend within the meaning of S. 35(10) so as to attract the applicability of the provisions enabling withdrawal of rebate and demand for tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: In the Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co.s case it was held that power to withdraw rebate granted in the year before April 1, 1952 was not exercisable by the Income-tax Officer under S. 35(10) and consistently with that view withdrawal of rebate granted in the years ending on and before March 31, 1952 was unauthorised.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. S. G. Mehta

petitioner_arguments.text: Power under sub-s. (10) of s. 35 cannot be exercised because distribution of accumulated profits by the liquidator is not distribution by the Company.

On the commencement of winding up, distinction between the capital and accumulated profits of the Company disappears, and what remains in the hands of the liquidator are the assets of the Company, and distributions made by the liquidator are distributions of capital, regardless of the source from which the funds are distributed is capital or accumulated profits.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell

petitioner_arguments.text: Assuming that accumulated profits of a Company distributed by the liquidator may be regarded as dividends, power under s. 35(10) cannot be exercised in respect of those profits, because the liquidator is not in distributing the profits declaring dividends.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Companies Act provisions on declaration of dividends

court_reasoning.text: The first question is concluded by a recent judgment of this Court in Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. S. G. Mehta, Income-tax Officer and Another. In that case this Court held that s. 35(10) applied even though dividend was declared before April 1, 1956.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The argument raised by counsel importing a limitation contrary to the plain words of the statute must therefore be rejected.

court_reasoning.text: The argument is wholly without substance. On the passing of a special resolution by the Company that it be wound up voluntarily under the Companies Act 1 of 1956, the Company does not stand dissolved... The liquidator appointed in a members winding up is merely an agent of the Company to administer the property of the Company for purposes prescribed by the statute. In distributing the assets including accumulated profits the liquidator acts merely as an agent or administrator for and on behalf of the Company.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distribution by liquidator is distribution by the Company.

court_reasoning.text: Under the Companies Act, 1956, accumulated profits of the Company at the commencement of the winding up of the Company undoubtedly come into the hands of the liquidator as assets... But the rule in Burrells case since the amendment of the definition of dividend in s. 2(6A) by the Finance Act, 1956, no longer applies... Clause (c) as originally enacted, included distributions made to the shareholders of a Company out of accumulated profits on the liquidation of the Company. This was clearly an attempt to supersede the rule in Burrells case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distributions by liquidator out of accumulated profits are dividends under s.2(6A)(c).

court_reasoning.text: It would be reasonable to regard the provisions of s. 35(10) and amended cl. (c) of sub-s. (6A) of s. 2 as part of a single scheme to declare distribution of accumulated profits, capitalized or not, as dividends, and to bring the rebate granted on undistributed profits to tax if availed of by the company or by the liquidator of a company for distributing dividends.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.35(10) and s.2(6A)(c) form a single scheme.

court_reasoning.text: Distribution of accumulated profits by a Company not subject to winding up is distribution of dividend by virtue of S. 2(6A)(a), and distribution of accumulated profits in the course of liquidation is dividend by virtue of s. 2(6A)(c).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No warrant for distinction between company and its liquidator.

court_reasoning.text: The liquidator of the appellant company did from time to time distribute accumulated profits, and within the meaning of s. 2(6A)(c) read with the provisions of the Companies Act, they were distribution of interim dividends... Distribution of accumulated profits by the liquidator together with the income-tax refund certificate in the course of voluntary winding up may therefore, for the purpose of s. 2(6A)(c), be regarded as declaration of dividend.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Liquidator's distributions are declaration of dividend for s.35(10).

holdings.text: s. 35(10) applied even though dividend was declared before April 1, 1956; power to withdraw rebate is exercisable within four years from the end of the financial year in which the amount of rebate was availed of.

Distribution by the liquidator of accumulated profits in the previous years could be regarded as declaration of dividend within the meaning of S. 35(10) so as to attract the applicability of the provisions enabling withdrawal of rebate and demand for tax.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. S. G. Mehta, Income-tax Officer and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that s. 35(10) applied even though dividend was declared before April 1, 1956; power exercisable within four years from end of relevant financial year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule that distributions in winding up are not income no longer applies after amendments to s.2(6A).

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhandhania Kedia Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: s. 2(6A)(c) enacted to supersede Burrell's case and treat liquidator distributions as dividends.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: s.35(10) empowers withdrawal of rebate if accumulated profits used for dividends; s.2(6A)(c) defines dividend to include liquidator distributions out of accumulated profits.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Company not dissolved on voluntary winding up resolution; liquidator is agent of company; property vests in company.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs declaration and distribution of dividends, including interim dividends by directors or liquidator.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted s.35(10) and recast s.2(6A)(c) as part of single scheme to tax rebates on dividends from accumulated profits.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed as both issues are decided against the appellant company, upholding the Income-tax Officer's orders withdrawing rebates under s.35(10) and the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition.

key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Links the provisions to treat liquidator distributions as dividends attracting rebate withdrawal.
